title: Amy Coney Barrett deserves a seat at the table despite abortion foes
description: Instead of denigrating Judge Barrett, we should celebrate the fact that Roe v. Wade could some day be returned to the individual states to decide
text_headers: Amy Coney Barrett should have a seat at the table. She is the epitome of empowerment
text: Amy Coney Barrett deserves a seat at the table despite abortion foesNews Sports Kentucky Derby Life Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  OPINIONAmy Coney Barrett should have a seat at the table. She is the epitome of empowermentSchu MontgomeryOpinion contributorIt’s always been about abortion.   The assassination or attempted assassination of an otherwise well-qualified jurist to the Supreme Court hinges on whether or not that judge is poised to overrule the infamous Roe v. Wade decision, legalizing abortion through all nine months of a woman’s pregnancy.The “borking” (derived from the besmirching of Reagan-nominee Robert Bork in 1987) of one originalist-type judge after another remains the raison d’être of Democrat ideologues. President Trump’s pick for the next justice of the Supreme Court, Judge Amy Coney Barrett of the 7th Circuit Court, stands in the crosshairs of many judicial activists, whose faux feminism foists the nebulous abortion “choice” on the backs of countless dead babies.More:17 ways abortion could be outlawed in Kentucky with Amy Coney Barrett on the Supreme CourtStellar recommendations from colleagues and former students, unmatched intellect, devoted mother of seven (two adopted from Haiti, another with Down syndrome), and a principled commitment to interpreting the Constitution as written, not legislating from the bench — be damned! This is the intolerable mindset of those vehemently opposed to the Barrett appointment.Reflecting on Judge Barrett’s appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said, “Judge Barrett demonstrated that she has deep legal expertise, dispassionate judicial temperament, and sheer intellectual horsepower that the American people deserve to have on their Supreme Court.”For nearly a half-century, pro-life activists have had to endure the injustice of Roe — the death of nearly 65 million unborn babies, the wounding of countless women who regret their abortions — all in the name of a “right” nowhere found in the Constitution.The job of a judge — particularly on the nation’s highest court — is to interpret the law, not make it. Judge Barrett herself has insisted, “A judge must apply the law as written, not as the judge wishes it were.” She adds, “Judges are not policymakers, and they must be resolute in setting aside any policy views they may hold.”Earlier:Kentucky AG Daniel Cameron signs letter asking Senate to quickly confirm Amy Coney BarrettRecently, a pro-life activist was struck in the face by a self-described “feminist” for carrying a sign that read, “I can’t believe feminists are protesting a woman (Judge Barrett).” Autumn Schimmer later told the media that “women deserve better than abortion and are not empowered by killing their children.”Amy Coney Barrett is the epitome of empowerment. She is a modern-day success story. Bonnie Finnerty, education director for the Pennsylvania Pro-Life Federation, calls Barrett, “the new face of feminism.” Finnerty writes, “Her (Barrett’s) life itself is a message to present and future generations of women that true feminism is not an either/or proposition that limits your roles, but an and/both invitation to fulfill your potential.”Kristan Hawkins of Students for Life describes Barrett as “one of us” because she is a working mother. “By merit and hard work, she has advanced, and, if confirmed, she will become the first mother with school-age children to serve on the Supreme Court.” No one has a crystal ball as to how Judge Barrett, once on the high court, will rule on Roe. While on the 7th Circuit, she did vote to allow a hearing on a pro-life Indiana law requiring abortion centers to offer proper burial or cremation for babies killed in abortions. And she sided with another law allowing parents to be notified when their teenage daughter was considering an abortion. In addition, as a law professor, Barrett professed the conviction of the value of human like from conception to natural death. For millions of pro-life Americans, that’s a laudable thing, not shameful.Instead of denigrating Judge Barrett, we should celebrate the fact that a decision (Roe) that was once dubbed an “exercise in raw judicial power,” could some day be returned to the individual states — in essence, to the people — as the rightful place for resolving longstanding, contentious social issues, like abortion.Opinion:The Supreme Court battle isn't really about the sanctity of judicial precedentSchu Montgomery is a member of the board of directors for Right to Life of Louisville.Staff Directory Careers Accessibility Support Site Map Legals Our Ethical Principles Responsible Disclosure Subscription Terms & Conditions Terms of Service Privacy Policy Your Privacy ChoicesContact Us Support Local Businesses Advertise Your Business Advertising Terms and Conditions Promote your Event Buy and Sell Promote Your Event Licensing & Reprints Help Center Courier Journal Store Subscriber Guide Manage Account Give Feedback Promote Your EventSubscribe Today Newsletters Mobile Apps Facebook X eNewspaper ArchivesJobs Cars Homes Classifieds Education Events Reviewed 10Best LocaliQ Digital Marketing Solutions Events© 2024 www.courier-journal.com.
